docs.lead_paragraph: After analyzing six decades of expert research on corporal punishment, a psychologist says parents who spank their children risk long-term harm that outweighs the short-term benefit of instant obedience. The psychologist, Dr. Elizabeth Gershoff, found links between spanking and 10 negative behaviors or experiences, including aggression, antisocial behavior and mental health problems. The one positive result of spanking that Dr. Gershoff identified was quick compliance with parental demands.

headline.main: A New Look At Effects Of Spanking

docs.abstract: Psychologist Dr Elizabeth Gershoff, in analysis of six decades of research on corporal punishment published in The American Psychological Assn journal, concludes that parents who spank their children put them at risk for long-term harm, including aggression, antisocial behavior and mental health problems; urges parents who spank, especially those with abusive tendencies, to reconsider options (M)
docs.snippet: After analyzing six decades of expert research on corporal punishment, a psychologist says parents who spank their children risk long-term harm that outweighs the short-term benefit of instant obedience.    The psychologist, Dr. Elizabeth Gershoff,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since his baby days, Alex, now nearly 4, has been a puzzle to his parents. As an infant, he screamed unless he was being rocked or held. He hated the feel of water; baths were a nightmare. By 3, he was covering his ears at loud noises. He loved the feel of the sandbox, but could not stand sock fuzz between his toes. Sleep came only in fits and starts. ''He was,'' Alex's father says, ''kind of like a raw nerve.''

headline.main: Debating Diagnosis of a Sensory Malady in Children

docs.abstract: Article on sensory integration dysfunction, baffling condition in children regarded by many occupational therapists as neurological disorder in which children are either overstimulated by noises, touch and overactivity or seem understimulated and need to move all the time; some medical doctors do not believe condition exists and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention does not track it as disease; case of four-year-old Alex detailed; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has concluded that for many scalp wounds, taking a few strands of hair from each side of the wound, twisting them together and gluing them into place may be a better treatment than stitching. The study, which was published in the July issue of The Annals of Emergency Medicine, found that the technique was not only less painful, it also allowed simple wounds to heal faster and with fewer side effects. Dr. Adam J. Singer of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, who wrote an accompanying editorial, said emergency room doctors in several countries, but primarily Britain, had experimented with closing scalp wounds by tying hair across them into knots. But Dr. Singer said he and others had tried and rejected that because the knots tended to slip.

headline.main: A New Hair Weave That Heals

docs.abstract: Dr Marcus Ong Eng Hock of Singapore General Hospital, in study published in The Annals of Emergency Medicine, concludes that twisting together strands of hair from both sides of a superficial head wound and gluing them in place may be better than stitching; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A new study has concluded that for many scalp wounds, taking a few strands of hair from each side of the wound, twisting them together and gluing them into place may be a better treatment than stitching. The study, which was published in the July...

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug used to treat Alzheimer's disease slightly helped airline pilots retain their training in a complex flight test, a study published today has found. In the study, 18 pilots were put through a series of maneuvers in a simulator seven times. For the next month, they were given daily doses either of donepezil, also known as Aricept, or a placebo, and they were tested again. The group given the medicine did better, particularly on emergency responses and approaches to runways.
docs.abstract: Study led by Stanford University researcher Dr Jerome A Yesavage, published in journal Neurology, finds that donepezil (Aricept), drug used to treat Alzheimer's disease, slightly helped airline pilots retain their training in complex flight test; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A drug used to treat Alzheimer's disease slightly helped airline pilots retain their training in a complex flight test, a study published today has found.    In the study, 18 pilots were put through a series of maneuvers in a simulator seven times....

docs.lead_paragraph: The common faint was enshrined in my adolescent imagination by movies. Remember the beautiful heroine -- fainters on film are always women -- overcome by shock, touching her brow with the back of her hand and falling limply into waiting arms. Her faint was stereotyped and contrived -- yet riveting. It made fainting seem benign, almost glamorous. When I became a doctor, fainting started to be called syncope, a decidedly less romantic disease. ''Syncopizers'' were some of the most dreaded patients we saw in the emergency room -- they account for 3 to 5 percent of all E.R. visits -- because you never knew what to do with them.

headline.main: Beyond the Script: What Happens When the Heroine Faints

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar article on vasovagal syncope, commonly known as fainting; describes how vasovagal syncope occurs, its symptoms and diagnostic test; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: We were an unlikely group, the three of us, united only by our being blindsided by a medical anomaly that we share with hundreds of other women. Lori Levy, a registered nurse, had never heard of it when she woke up six years ago, temporarily unable to string words together.

headline.main: Blindsided By a Tumor Few Study

docs.abstract: Cases column by Joan McQueeney on meningiomas, brain tumors that, whether malignant or benign, are twice as common in women than men; almost no research is being done on what causes them, but female hormones are thought to play role in disease; says tumors, depending on size and location, can severely disable or kill people, nearly 20 percent recur, sometimes repeatedly, and small percentage become aggressive cancers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you've heard of endometriosis at all, chances are you think it's just a woman's problem. And, to be sure, only women and adolescent girls can develop it. But it can affect everyone in the family in two ways: by causing repetitive life-disrupting pain and other symptoms and by signaling in relatives, both men and women, as well as the woman herself, an increased risk of developing severe allergies, autoimmune diseases and possibly cancer.

headline.main: Painful Signs of Endometriosis Should Be Taken Seriously

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column describes symptoms, possible causes, risk factors and treatment of endometriosis; disease, once believed to be solely endocrine disorder, has strong immunological connection that may be hereditary; drawing; self-test (M)

Norton & Company, $26.95 Dr. Lopez began working in his specialty in the early 1970's when it was still fairly new, and when American teenagers were winning little sympathy from adults.

docs.lead_paragraph: In rural India, treatment for mental illness is more likely to come in a ''healing temple'' than in a clinic or hospital. In a study published on Saturday in The British Medical Journal, a psychiatrist who evaluated a small group of patients at such a temple reported finding signs of significant improvement. The study, led by Dr. R. Raguram of India's National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences, involved a temple in a village built 60 years ago on the gravesite of a man thought to have healing powers.

headline.main: Gentle Refuge for Patients in India

docs.abstract: Study led by India's National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences researcher Dr R Raguram, published in British Medical Journal, finds signs of significant improvement in mental illness among small group of patients treated at rural 'healing temple;' drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 20 years since a vaccine against hepatitis B was introduced, new infections in the United States have dropped to 80,000 a year from more than 200,000, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. The number of children infected each year has dropped even more sharply, according to an article in the agency's journal, The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.

headline.main: Progress in the Hepatitis B Fight

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control, in Morbidity and Mortalilty Weekly Report, says new hepatitis B infections in US have dropped to 80,000 a year from more than 200,000 in two decades since introduction of vaccine; says number of children infected has dropped even more sharply (M)
